tn.text: Often in prophecy events that will happen in future are described as happening now or in the past. This emphasizes that the event will certainly happen. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pastforfuture]])
"This is what Yahweh declares" or "This is a message from Yahweh"
These are names of cities and towns in Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Ar of Moab is laid waste and destroyed
tn.text: The words "laid waste" and "destroyed" mean the same thing and emphasize that the city was completely ruined. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Enemy armies will completely destroy Ar of Moab" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: went up to the heights to weep
tn.text: Here "up to the heights" refers to a temple or altar that was built on high ground like a hill or mountain side. AT: "went up to the temple on the hilltop to weep" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Moab laments over Nebo and over Medeba
tn.text: These place names refer to the people who live there. AT: "the people of Moab will weep because of what happened to the cities of Nebo and Medeba" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: All their heads are shaved bare and all their beards are cut off
tn.text: They do this to show their extreme sadness. AT" "They will all shave their heads and cut off their beards and grieve" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
This continues the prophecy about the people of Moab. God describes events that will happen in the future as if it is happening in the present. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:isa:15:01|15:1-2]])
They do this to show their extreme sadness. AT: "they wear sackcloth and mourn" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
These are names of cities and towns. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These city names represent the people of these cities. "The people of Heshbon and Elealeh call out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Physical trembling is a symptom of fear. AT: "they will be completely filled with fear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This continues the prophecy about the people of Moab. God describes events that will happen in the future as if it is happening in the present. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:isa:15:01|15:1-2]])

tn.ref: My heart cries out for Moab
tn.text: The heart represents the emotions. God speaks of his great sadness as if his heart cried out. AT: "I am extremely sad about what is happening to Moab" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] or [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"the fugitives from Moab will flee." A fugitive is a person who runs away so that his enemy will not capture him.

tn.ref: Zoar ... Eglath Shelishiyah ... Luhith ... Horonaim ... Nimrim
tn.text: These are names of cities and towns. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This can be reworded so that the abstract noun "destruction" is expressed as the verb "destroyed." AT: "because their city is destroyed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"Everything"
This may refer to the river at the southern border of Moab.
This continues the prophecy about the people of Moab. God describes events that will happen in the future as if it is happening in the present. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:isa:15:01|15:1-2]])

tn.ref: The cry has gone around the territory of Moab
tn.text: People's crying out and others hearing it is spoken of as if the cry had gone out. AT: "People all over the territory of Moab cry out"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the wailing as far as Eglaim and Beer Elim
tn.text: The words "has gone" are understood. People's wailing and others hearing it is spoken of as if the wailing had gone as far away as these two places. AT: "the wailing has gone as far as Egalim and Beer Elim" or "people even as far away as Elaim and Beer Elim wail"
These are names of cities and towns. Dimon was the principal city of the country of Moab. Several modern versions have "Dibon" instead of "Dimon." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: but I will bring even more upon Dimon
tn.text: Here "I" refers to Yahweh. Also, "upon Dimon" refers to the people. AT: "but I will cause even more trouble for the people of Dimon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
